https://rog.asus.com/gaming-handhelds/rog-ally/rog-ally-2023/}} }} The '''Asus ROG Ally''' is a [[Handheld PC|handheld]] [[gaming computer]] developed and manufactured by [[Asus]] as part of their [[Republic of Gamers]] (ROG) brand. Released on June 13, 2023, the device competes with [[Valve Corporation|Valve]]'s [[Steam Deck]]. The ROG Ally runs the [[Windows 11]] [[operating system]] and uses an [[AMD]] [[Zen 4]] processor called the AMD Z1 and Z1 Extreme. In addition to handheld use, the ROG Ally can be connected to a TV or [[Computer monitor|monitor]] through a [[docking station]] or a dongle and be used like a [[desktop computer]] or [[home video game console]]. == History == [[Asus]] began developing a [[Handheld PC|handheld]] [[gaming computer]] in 2018 to compete with handheld computers such as the [[GPD Win 2]].{{Cite web |last=Williams |first=Leah J. |title=ASUS ROG Ally: How the Device Evolved in Its Five Year Journey |url=https://www.gameshub.com/news/features/asus-rog-ally-interview-five-year-development-console-2616764/ |access-date=June 20, 2023 |website=GamesHub |date=May 19, 2023 |publisher=ArtsHub Australia |language=en-AU}} Development slowed down over the next few years but was accelerated after [[Valve Corporation|Valve]]'s 2021 announcement of the [[Steam Deck]], which quickly led to a renewed public interest in handheld gaming computers.{{Cite news |last=James |first=Dave |date=April 25, 2023 |title=Asus has been building the ROG Ally for 5 years and here are the hideous prototypes to prove it |language=en |work=PC Gamer |publisher=Future US |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/asus-has-been-building-the-rog-ally-for-5-years-and-here-are-the-hideous-prototypes-to-prove-it/ |access-date=June 20, 2023}} The device was announced on April 1, 2023, leading many to believe it is an [[April Fools' Day]] prank,{{Cite web |last=Peters |first=Jay |date=April 4, 2023 |title=Asus announced its handheld gaming PC in the worst way possible |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/4/4/23669875/asus-rog-ally-handheld-gaming-pc-announcement |access-date=June 20, 2023 |website=The Verge |publisher=Vox Media |language=en-US}} with Asus clarifying its legitimacy three days later.{{Cite web |last=Brown |first=Andy |date=April 3, 2023 |title=Asus confirms its ROG Ally handheld gaming PC wasn't an April Fool's Day prank |url=https://www.nme.com/news/gaming-news/asus-confirm-rog-ally-handheld-gaming-pc-wasnt-april-fools-day-prank-3425147 |access-date=June 20, 2023 |website=NME |language=en-GB}} Asus revealed the ROG Ally's release date, technical specifications and price on June 11, 2023. Two models were announced, one retailing for {{USD|599}} and implementing a [[Ryzen]] Z1 Processor, and another retailing for {{USD|699}} and implementing a Ryzen Z1 Extreme processor.{{cite web | last=Spear | first=Rebecca | date=May 11, 2023 | url=https://www.windowscentral.com/gaming/pc-gaming/rog-ally-specs | title=ASUS ROG Ally full specs: AMD Ryzen Z1 Extreme, 512GB storage, 120Hz display and more | work=Windows Central | publisher=Future US | archiveurl= | archivedate=}} The latter was released on June 13, 2023, and the former will be released during the third quarter of 2023.{{cite web | last=Allen | first=Eric Van | date=May 11, 2023 | url=https://www.destructoid.com/asus-rog-ally-handheld-pc-price-date-details-models/ | title=Asus outlines price, date, and details for the ROG Ally | work=Destructoid | publisher=Gamurs Group | archiveurl= | archivedate=}} == Hardware == The ROG Ally implements an [[AMD APU]], based on AMD's [[Zen 4]] and [[RDNA 3]] architectures. Two different models of the ROG Ally were released, one with a [[Ryzen]] Z1 processor and another with a Ryzen Z1 Extreme.{{Cite web |title=ROG Ally (2023) RC71L Tech Specs |url=https://rog.asus.com/gaming-handhelds/rog-ally/rog-ally-2023/ |access-date=June 25, 2023 |website=[[Asus]].com |publisher=Asus |language=en}} The Z1 CPU runs a six-core/twelve-thread unit and the Z1 GPU runs on four [[compute unit]]s with a total estimated performance of 2.56 [[FLOPS|TFLOPS]].{{Cite web |title=AMD Ryzen Z1 General Specifications |url=https://www.amd.com/en/products/apu/amd-ryzen-z1 |website=[[AMD]].com |publisher=AMD}} The Z1 Extreme CPU runs an eight-core/sixteen-thread unit while its GPU runs on twelve compute units at an estimate of 8.29 TFLOPS{{ref|c}}.{{Cite web |title=AMD Ryzen Z1 Extreme General Specifications |url=https://www.amd.com/en/products/apu/amd-ryzen-z1-extreme |website=[[AMD]].com |publisher=AMD}} Both processors use variable timing frequencies, with the Z1 running between 3.2 and 4.9 [[Hertz|GHz]] and the Z1 Extreme running between 3.3 and 5.1 GHz. The main unit of the Ally is designed for handheld use. It features a 7-inch touchscreen [[Liquid-crystal display|LCD]] display with a [[1080p]] resolution and [[variable refresh rate]] that goes up to 120 Hz.{{cite web | last=Buzzi | first=Matthew | date=May 11, 2023 | url=https://www.pcmag.com/reviews/asus-rog-ally | title=Asus ROG Ally Review | work=PCMag | publisher=Ziff-Davis | archiveurl= | archivedate=}} Controls resemble those of an [[Xbox Wireless Controller]], including two [[Analog stick|thumbsticks]], a directional pad, A/B/X/Y buttons, two shoulder buttons on each side, and two configurable buttons on the back of the unit.{{cite web | last=Reid | first=Craig | date=May 11, 2023 | url=https://www.purexbox.com/news/2023/05/review-asus-rog-ally-the-xbox-handheld-weve-been-waiting-for | title=Review: ASUS ROG Ally – The Xbox Handheld We've Been Waiting For? | work=Pure Xbox | publisher=Hookshot Media | archiveurl= | archivedate=}} == Software == The ROG Ally ships with [[Windows 11|Windows 11 Home]] integrated with Armoury Crate SE, a software utility developed by Asus.{{Cite web |last=Kee |first=Kok |date=June 13, 2023 |title=Review – ROG Ally: Great handheld device, but with some caveats |url=https://www.tech-critter.com/review-rog-ally/ |access-date=June 24, 2023 |website=Tech Critter |publisher=Wavelength Network |language=en-US}} Armoury Crate lets the user quickly configure [[thermal design power]] with several pre-adjusted presets,{{Cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=May 11, 2023 |title=Asus ROG Ally updated review: it's a bit better now |url=https://www.theverge.com/23719210/asus-rog-ally-review |access-date=June 24, 2023 |website=The Verge |publisher=Vox Media |language=en-US}} as well as change the [[refresh rate]], screen resolution, limit [[frame rate]] and adjust [[clock rate]]s.{{Cite web |title=[ROG Ally] Armoury Crate SE Introduction |url=https://www.asus.com/us/support/FAQ/1050220/ |access-date=June 24, 2023 |website=Asus.com |publisher=Asus |language=en-US}} Armoury Crate also acts as a [[game launcher]], automatically compiling the user's game library from third-party launchers like [[Steam (service)|Steam]] and [[Epic Games Store]].{{Cite news |last=Leadbetter |first=Richard |date=May 20, 2023 |title=Asus ROG Ally vs Steam Deck: can powerful new tech deliver a game-changing handheld? |language=en-gb |work=Eurogamer.net |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/digitalfoundry-2023-asus-rog-ally-vs-steam-deck-review?page=2 |access-date=June 25, 2023}} Although [[Features new to Windows 11#Input|Windows 11 improved touchscreen support]], some interactions can only be done using a [[Cursor (user interface)|mouse cursor]]. Due to this, Armoury Crate lets users emulate a mouse using the left joystick.{{Cite web |last=Anderson |first=Robert |date=May 11, 2023 |title=Asus ROG Ally Review |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/asus-rog-ally-review |access-date=June 25, 2023 |website=[[IGN]] |publisher=Ziff-Davis |language=en}} The ROG Ally also ships with a three-month subscription to [[Xbox Game Pass]], a video game [[Subscription business model|subscription service]] from [[Microsoft]].{{cite web | last=Delgado | first=Camilo | date=June 20, 2023 | url=https://www.pcguide.com/console/asus-rog-ally-game-pass/ | title=Can Asus ROG Ally play Game Pass? | work=PC Guide | archiveurl= | archivedate=}} == Reception == The initial response to the ROG Ally was mixed. Tony Polanco of ''[[Tom's Guide]]'' described it as "solid but imperfect", complimenting its display and ergonomics but criticizing performance and battery life.{{Cite web |last=updated |first=Tony Polanco last |date=May 11, 2023 |title=Asus ROG Ally review: A solid but imperfect Steam Deck challenger |url=https://www.tomsguide.com/reviews/asus-rog-ally |access-date=June 24, 2023 |website=Tom's Guide |publisher=Future US |language=en}} In contrast to Polanco's review, Sean Hollister of ''[[The Verge]]'' praised the device's performance, but criticized Asus' choice of Windows 11 as an operating system, calling Windows "largely foreign" on a handheld form-factor. Writing for ''[[Eurogamer]]'', Richard Leadbetter wrote: "Various issues conspire to lend the impression that the ROG Ally isn't fully baked quite yet, while the Windows underpinnings may well be a limiting factor that may never be overcome."{{Cite news |last=Leadbetter |first=Richard |date=May 20, 2023 |title=Asus ROG Ally vs Steam Deck: can powerful new tech deliver a game-changing handheld? |language=en-gb |work=Eurogamer |publisher=Gamer Network |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/digitalfoundry-2023-asus-rog-ally-vs-steam-deck-review?page=2 |access-date=June 25, 2023}} A criticism highlighted by multiple reviews is the battery life. Hollister reported a 53-minute battery life playing ''[[The Last of Us Part I]]'' on the 25W [[Thermal design power|TDP]] profile, while Kevin Purdy of ''[[Ars Technica]]'' measured an 88-minute life playing ''[[The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt]]'' on the 15W profile.{{Cite web |last=Purdy |first=Kevin |date=May 11, 2023 |title=The Asus ROG Ally runs Windows, eats battery, and needs time to cook |url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2023/05/the-asus-rog-ally-runs-windows-eats-battery-and-needs-time-to-cook/ |access-date=June 25, 2023 |website=Ars Technica |publisher=Condé Nast |language=en-us}} Writing for ''[[Windows Central]]'', Rebecca Spear described battery life as "pretty atrocious",{{Cite web |last=Spear |first=Rebecca |date=June 14, 2023 |title=10 ways to improve ROG Ally gaming handheld battery life |url=https://www.windowscentral.com/gaming/pc-gaming/ways-to-improve-rog-ally-battery-life |access-date=June 25, 2023 |website=Windows Central |publisher=Future US |language=en}} though Anyron Copeman of ''[[Tech Advisor]]'' commented that the device's fast 65W charging capability makes up for its poor battery life.{{Cite web |last=Copeman |first=Anyron |title=Asus ROG Ally review: Powerful compromise |url=https://www.techadvisor.com/article/1816328/asus-rog-ally-review.html |access-date=June 25, 2023 |website=Tech Advisor |publisher=IDG Communications |language=en}} == Notes == {{notelist}} == See also == * [[Ayaneo]] * [[GPD Win Max]], another competitor device * [[Lenovo Legion Go]], another competitor device * [[Steam Deck]], another competitor device using SteamOS * [[Ultra-mobile PC]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|https://www.asus.com/us/site/gaming/rog/gaming-handheld/rog-ally.html}} [[Category:Asus products|ROG Ally]] [[Category:Computer-related introductions in 2023]] [[Category:Handheld gaming computers]] [[Category:Products introduced in 2023]] [[Category:X86-based computers]]
